title: A Second Rate Cut Lifts Stocks–Unless a Recession Hits
text:
A short-term rate cut is likely on its way. Core retail sales in August were mostly flat, which gave the Federal Reserve even more motivation for a dovish stance. But what could that mean for the stock market?

Ned Davis Research’s Ed Clissold and Thanh Nguyen wrote in a note on Tuesday that based on historical data, a second rate cut generally sends stocks up in the following year—unless it’s too late to hold off a recession. Clissold is chief U.S. strategist and Nguyen is Ned Davis’ senior quantitative analyst.
